text: ਰਾਮ ਸਿਮਰਿ ਰਾਮ ਸਿਮਰਿ ਰਾਮ ਸਿਮਰਿ ਭਾਈ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Remember the Lord, remember the Lord, remember the Lord in meditation, O Siblings of Destiny.

transliteration.text: rām simar rām simar rām simar bhāī .

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਰਾਮ ਨਾਮ ਸਿਮਰਨ ਬਿਨੁ ਬੂਡਤੇ ਅਧਿਕਾਈ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Without remembering the Lord's Name in meditation, a great many are drowned. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: rām nām simaran bin būdatē adhikāī .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਬਨਿਤਾ ਸੁਤ ਦੇਹ ਗ੍ਰੇਹ ਸੰਪਤਿ ਸੁਖਦਾਈ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Your spouse, children, body, house and possessions - you think these will give you peace.

transliteration.text: banitā sut dēh grēh sanpat sukhadāī .

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਇਨ੍ਹ ਮੈ ਕਛੁ ਨਾਹਿ ਤੇਰੋ ਕਾਲ ਅਵਧ ਆਈ ॥੧॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: But none of these shall be yours, when the time of death comes. ||1||

transliteration.text: inh mai kash nāh tērō kāl avadh āī .1.

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

author.description:

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਅਜਾਮਲ ਗਜ ਗਨਿਕਾ ਪਤਿਤ ਕਰਮ ਕੀਨੇ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Ajaamal, the elephant, and the prostitute committed many sins,

transliteration.text: ajāmal gaj ganikā patit karam kīnē .

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

author.description:

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. text: ਤੇਊ ਉਤਰਿ ਪਾਰਿ ਪਰੇ ਰਾਮ ਨਾਮ ਲੀਨੇ ॥੨॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: but still, they crossed over the world-ocean, by chanting the Lord's Name. ||2||

transliteration.text: tēū utar pār parē rām nām līnē .2.

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

text: ਸੂਕਰ ਕੂਕਰ ਜੋਨਿ ਭ੍ਰਮੇ ਤਊ ਲਾਜ ਨ ਆਈ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: You have wandered in reincarnation, as pigs and dogs - did you feel no shame?

transliteration.text: sūkar kūkar jōn bhramē taū lāj n āī .

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

text: ਰਾਮ ਨਾਮ ਛਾਡਿ ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤ ਕਾਹੇ ਬਿਖੁ ਖਾਈ ॥੩॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Forsaking the Ambrosial Name of the Lord, why do you eat poison? ||3||

transliteration.text: rām nām shād anmrit kāhē bikh khāī .3.

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

text: ਤਜਿ ਭਰਮ ਕਰਮ ਬਿਧਿ ਨਿਖੇਧ ਰਾਮ ਨਾਮੁ ਲੇਹੀ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Abandon your doubts about do's and dont's, and take to the Lord's Name.

transliteration.text: taj bharam karam bidh nikhēdh rām nām lēhī .

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

text: ਗੁਰ ਪ੍ਰਸਾਦਿ ਜਨ ਕਬੀਰ ਰਾਮੁ ਕਰਿ ਸਨੇਹੀ ॥੪॥੫॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: By Guru's Grace, O servant Kabeer, love the Lord. ||4||5||

transliteration.text: gur prasād jan kabīr rām kar sanēhī .4.5.
